page.textbox:
Lithium Batteries Transported as Cargo
Lithium Batteries Transported as Cargo

-A pallet that had been off loaded from a Northwest Airline flight from Japan ignited on the ground at Los Angeles International airport. The pallet had been tipped over by a forklift. The fire started soon after the pallet had been righted. Part of the pallet load was 120,000 lithium primary batteries.
-A pallet that had been off loaded from a Northwest Airline flight from Japan ignited
on the ground at Los Angeles International airport. The pallet had been tipped over by
a forklift. The fire started soon after the pallet had been righted. Part of the pallet load
was 120,000 lithium primary batteries.

-The total quantity of small lithium batteries that can be shipped is currently unregulated because the quantity of lithium per battery is relatively low.
-The total quantity of small lithium batteries that can be shipped is currently
unregulated because the quantity of lithium per battery is relatively low.

-The NFPA does not consider Halon 1301 an acceptable agent to use on lithium fires.
-The NFPA does not consider Halon 1301 an acceptable agent to use on lithium fires.

-Lithium reacts strongly with water forming highly explosive hydrogen gas.
-Lithium reacts strongly with water forming highly explosive hydrogen gas.

-Testing has been started to determine the ability of Halon 1301 to control a cargo fire involving large quantities of small lithium batteries.
-Testing has been started to determine the ability of Halon 1301 to control a cargo fire
involving large quantities of small lithium batteries.

Pallet containing 120,000 lithium batteries involved in ground fire at LAX.

lithium batteries involved
in ground fire at LAX.

Unburned CR2 batteries from pallet. Batteries of this type are typically shipped 1000 batteries per box.
